name: Hydrogen
summary: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant chemical element in the universe. It is colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, and highly combustible.

name: Helium
summary: Helium is a noble gas, colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, inert, monatomic. It has the lowest boiling point of all elements.

name: Lithium
summary: Lithium is a soft, silver-white metal belonging to the alkali metal group. It is the lightest metal and lightest solid element.

name: Beryllium
summary: Beryllium is a steel-gray, strong, lightweight metal. It has one of the highest melting points of the light metals.

name: Boron
summary: Boron is a metalloid element that exists in several allotropes. It is essential for plant growth and has many industrial applications.

name: Carbon
summary: Carbon is the basis of all known life. It can form more compounds than any other element due to its ability to form stable bonds.

name: Nitrogen
summary: Nitrogen is a colorless, odorless diatomic gas. It makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere and is essential for life.

name: Oxygen
summary: Oxygen is a highly reactive nonmetal and oxidizing agent. It makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere and is essential for respiration.

name: Fluorine
summary: Fluorine is the most electronegative element and extremely reactive. It is a pale yellow gas that reacts with almost all other elements.

name: Neon
summary: Neon is a noble gas that is colorless, odorless, inert under standard conditions. It gives a distinct reddish-orange glow in signs.

name: Sodium
summary: Sodium is a soft, silvery-white, highly reactive alkali metal. It is an essential element for all animals and some plants.

name: Magnesium
summary: Magnesium is a shiny gray solid. It is an alkaline earth metal and the eighth-most-abundant element in the Earth's crust.

name: Aluminum
summary: Aluminum is a silvery-white, soft, nonmagnetic, ductile metal. It is the third most abundant element in the Earth's crust.

name: Silicon
summary: Silicon is a hard and brittle crystalline solid with a blue-gray metallic luster. It is a crucial element in electronics and solar cells.

name: Phosphorus
summary: Phosphorus is a nonmetal that exists in several allotropes, including white (or yellow), red, and black. It is essential for life.

name: Sulfur
summary: Sulfur is a bright yellow, crystalline solid at room temperature. It is used in fertilizers, gunpowder, matches, and insecticides.

name: Chlorine
summary: Chlorine is a yellow-green gas at room temperature. It is a highly reactive element and a strong oxidizing agent.

name: Argon
summary: Argon is a noble gas that is colorless, odorless, and inert under most conditions. It is the third-most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere.

name: Potassium
summary: Potassium is a silvery-white metal that is soft enough to be cut with a knife. It is essential for all living cells.

name: Calcium
summary: Calcium is a reactive alkaline earth metal. It is the fifth most abundant element in Earth's crust and essential for living organisms.

name: Scandium
summary: Scandium is a silvery-white metallic transition metal. It is often classified as a rare earth element.

name: Titanium
summary: Titanium is a strong, lustrous transition metal with a silver color. It is highly resistant to corrosion.

name: Vanadium
summary: Vanadium is a hard, silvery-grey, malleable transition metal. It is used mainly to produce specialty steel alloys.

name: Chromium
summary: Chromium is a steely-grey, lustrous, hard and brittle transition metal. It is the main additive in stainless steel.

name: Manganese
summary: Manganese is a silvery-gray metal that resembles iron. It is essential to steel production and is used in many alloys.

name: Iron
summary: Iron is a lustrous, ductile, malleable, silver-gray metal. It is the most common element on Earth by mass.

name: Cobalt
summary: Cobalt is a hard, lustrous, silver-gray metal. It is used in the production of magnetic, wear-resistant and high-strength alloys.

name: Nickel
summary: Nickel is a silvery-white lustrous metal with a slight golden tinge. It is used in stainless steel and other corrosion-resistant alloys.

name: Copper
summary: Copper is a soft, malleable, and ductile metal with very high thermal and electrical conductivity.

name: Zinc
summary: Zinc is a slightly brittle metal at room temperature and has a blue-silver appearance. It is used for galvanizing iron and steel.

name: Gallium
summary: Gallium is a soft, silvery metal at standard temperature and pressure. It melts slightly above room temperature.

name: Germanium
summary: Germanium is a lustrous, hard, grayish-white metalloid. It is an important semiconductor material.

name: Arsenic
summary: Arsenic is a metalloid that occurs in many minerals. It has various allotropes, but only the gray form is important to industry.

name: Selenium
summary: Selenium is a nonmetal with properties intermediate between sulfur and tellurium. It is essential for some enzymes.

name: Bromine
summary: Bromine is a red-brown liquid at room temperature. It is a volatile and toxic element, part of the halogen group.

name: Krypton
summary: Krypton is a colorless, odorless, tasteless noble gas. It is used in certain photographic flashes and high-powered lamps.

name: Rubidium
summary: Rubidium is a very soft, silvery-white metal. It is an alkali metal and is highly reactive, similar to sodium and potassium.

name: Strontium
summary: Strontium is a soft silver-white yellowish metallic element. It is an alkaline earth metal and is highly chemically reactive.

name: Yttrium
summary: Yttrium is a silvery-metallic transition metal. It is often classified as a rare earth element and used in LEDs and phosphors.

name: Zirconium
summary: Zirconium is a lustrous, gray-white, strong transition metal. It is highly resistant to corrosion and used in nuclear reactors.

name: Niobium
summary: Niobium is a soft, grey, ductile transition metal. It is used in superconducting magnets and high-strength steel alloys.

name: Molybdenum
summary: Molybdenum is a silvery-white metal. It has one of the highest melting points of all pure elements and is used in steel alloys.

name: Technetium
summary: Technetium is a silvery-gray radioactive metal. It is the lightest element whose isotopes are all radioactive.

name: Ruthenium
summary: Ruthenium is a rare transition metal belonging to the platinum group. It is inert to most other chemicals.

name: Rhodium
summary: Rhodium is a rare, silvery-white, hard, corrosion-resistant transition metal. It is a member of the platinum group.

name: Palladium
summary: Palladium is a shiny, silvery-white metal. It is a member of the platinum group and is used in catalytic converters.

name: Silver
summary: Silver is a soft, white, lustrous transition metal. It has the highest electrical conductivity of any element.

name: Cadmium
summary: Cadmium is a soft, bluish-white metal. It is similar to zinc and mercury and is used in batteries and pigments.

name: Indium
summary: Indium is a soft, silvery-white metal. It is a post-transition metal and is used in touch screens and transparent conductive coatings.

name: Tin
summary: Tin is a silvery-white metal. It is malleable and used to coat other metals to prevent corrosion, as in tin cans.

name: Antimony
summary: Antimony is a lustrous gray metalloid. It is found in nature mainly as the sulfide mineral stibnite.

name: Tellurium
summary: Tellurium is a brittle, mildly toxic, rare, silver-white metalloid. It is chemically related to selenium and sulfur.

name: Iodine
summary: Iodine is a lustrous, purple-black non-metal that sublimes easily to form a violet gas. It is essential for thyroid function.

name: Xenon
summary: Xenon is a dense, colorless, odorless noble gas. It is used in flash lamps and as a general anesthetic.

name: Cesium
summary: Cesium is a soft, silvery-gold alkali metal. It is the most electropositive and alkaline element.

name: Barium
summary: Barium is a soft, silvery alkaline earth metal. Its compounds are used in fireworks, glassmaking, and oil drilling fluids.

name: Lanthanum
summary: Lanthanum is a soft, ductile, silvery-white metal. It is the first element of the lanthanide series.

name: Cerium
summary: Cerium is a soft, ductile, silvery-white metal. It is the most abundant of the rare earth elements.

name: Praseodymium
summary: Praseodymium is a soft, silvery, malleable and ductile metal. It is used in rare earth magnets and as a green colorant in glass.

name: Neodymium
summary: Neodymium is a soft, silvery metal that tarnishes in air. It is used to make powerful neodymium magnets.

name: Promethium
summary: Promethium is a radioactive rare earth metal. All its isotopes are radioactive; it is one of only two such elements followed by stable elements on the periodic table.

name: Samarium
summary: Samarium is a hard, silvery metal. It is used in samarium-cobalt magnets, which are highly resistant to demagnetization.

name: Europium
summary: Europium is a moderately hard, silvery metal. It is the most reactive rare earth element and is used in fluorescent lamps and TV screens.

name: Gadolinium
summary: Gadolinium is a silvery-white, malleable rare earth metal. It has unusual metallurgical properties and is used in MRI contrast agents.

name: Terbium
summary: Terbium is a silvery-white rare earth metal. It is used in solid-state devices and as a dopant in materials that fluoresce.

name: Dysprosium
summary: Dysprosium is a rare earth element with a metallic, bright silver luster. It is used in neodymium-based magnets to improve high-temperature performance.

name: Holmium
summary: Holmium is a relatively soft, malleable, silvery-white rare earth metal. It has the highest magnetic strength of any element.

name: Erbium
summary: Erbium is a silvery-white rare earth metal. It is used in optical fibers and amplifiers for telecommunications.

name: Thulium
summary: Thulium is a silvery-gray rare earth metal. It is the least abundant of the naturally occurring rare earth elements.

name: Ytterbium
summary: Ytterbium is a soft, malleable, ductile rare earth element with a bright silvery luster. It is used in some steels and lasers.

name: Lutetium
summary: Lutetium is a silvery-white rare earth metal. It is the last element in the lanthanide series and is sometimes considered a transition metal.

name: Hafnium
summary: Hafnium is a lustrous, silvery gray, tetravalent transition metal. It is used in nuclear reactor control rods because of its ability to absorb neutrons.

name: Tantalum
summary: Tantalum is a rare, hard, blue-gray, lustrous transition metal. It is highly corrosion-resistant and is used in electronic components.

name: Tungsten
summary: Tungsten is a rare metal with the highest melting point of all elements. It is used in light bulb filaments and heavy metal alloys.

name: Rhenium
summary: Rhenium is a silvery-white, heavy, transition metal. It has the third-highest melting point of any element and is used in high-temperature superalloys.

name: Osmium
summary: Osmium is a hard, brittle, bluish-white transition metal. It is the densest naturally occurring element.

name: Iridium
summary: Iridium is a very hard, brittle, silvery-white transition metal. It is the most corrosion-resistant metal, even at high temperatures.

name: Platinum
summary: Platinum is a dense, malleable, ductile, highly unreactive, precious, silverish-white transition metal. It is used in catalytic converters and jewelry.

name: Gold
summary: Gold is a bright, slightly reddish yellow, dense, soft, malleable, and ductile metal. It is one of the least reactive chemical elements.

name: Mercury
summary: Mercury is a heavy, silvery d-block element. It is the only metallic element that is liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure.

name: Thallium
summary: Thallium is a soft, malleable, gray post-transition metal. It is highly toxic and was used in rodent poisons and insecticides.

name: Lead
summary: Lead is a heavy metal that is denser than most common materials. It is soft, malleable, and has a relatively low melting point.

name: Bismuth
summary: Bismuth is a brittle metal with a white, silver-pink hue. It has one of the lowest thermal conductivity values among metals.

name: Polonium
summary: Polonium is a rare and highly radioactive metalloid. It is chemically similar to selenium and tellurium.

name: Astatine
summary: Astatine is a radioactive element and the heaviest known halogen. All its isotopes are short-lived.

name: Radon
summary: Radon is a radioactive, colorless, odorless, tasteless noble gas. It is formed from the decay of radium and is a health hazard.

name: Francium
summary: Francium is a highly radioactive alkali metal. It is the second-least electronegative element and extremely rare in nature.

name: Radium
summary: Radium is a radioactive alkaline earth metal. It was once used in luminous paints, but this use was discontinued due to its toxicity.

name: Actinium
summary: Actinium is a soft, silvery-white radioactive metal. It glows in the dark with a pale blue light due to its intense radioactivity.

name: Thorium
summary: Thorium is a weakly radioactive metallic chemical element. It is more abundant than uranium and is being researched as a nuclear fuel.

name: Protactinium
summary: Protactinium is a dense, silvery-gray actinide metal. It is highly radioactive, toxic, and scarce in nature.

name: Uranium
summary: Uranium is a silvery-gray metal in the actinide series. It is weakly radioactive and is the most common fuel used in nuclear power plants.

name: Neptunium
summary: Neptunium is a radioactive actinide metal. It is the first transuranic element and can be used to produce plutonium-238.

name: Plutonium
summary: Plutonium is a radioactive actinide metal. Its most important isotope is plutonium-239, which is used in nuclear weapons and reactors.

name: Americium
summary: Americium is a radioactive transuranic element. It is used in smoke detectors as an ionization source.

name: Curium
summary: Curium is a hard, dense, silvery actinide metal. It is highly radioactive and is produced by neutron irradiation of plutonium.

name: Berkelium
summary: Berkelium is a radioactive actinide element. It is produced in minute amounts in nuclear reactors and has no practical applications outside research.

name: Californium
summary: Californium is a radioactive actinide element. It is used as a neutron source to start nuclear reactors and in portable metal detectors.

name: Einsteinium
summary: Einsteinium is a synthetic, highly radioactive actinide element. It was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion.

name: Fermium
summary: Fermium is a synthetic, highly radioactive actinide element. It is produced by neutron bombardment of lighter actinides.

name: Mendelevium
summary: Mendelevium is a synthetic, highly radioactive actinide element. It was the first element to be synthesized one atom at a time.

name: Nobelium
summary: Nobelium is a synthetic, highly radioactive actinide element. It was named after Alfred Nobel, the founder of the Nobel Prize.

name: Lawrencium
summary: Lawrencium is a synthetic, highly radioactive actinide element. It is the last element in the actinide series.

name: Rutherfordium
summary: Rutherfordium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is the first transactinide element and is named after physicist Ernest Rutherford.

name: Dubnium
summary: Dubnium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after the town of Dubna in Russia, where it was first produced.

name: Seaborgium
summary: Seaborgium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Glenn T. Seaborg, who was instrumental in the discovery of many transuranium elements.

name: Bohrium
summary: Bohrium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Niels Bohr, the Danish physicist who made fundamental contributions to atomic structure.

name: Hassium
summary: Hassium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after the German state of Hesse, where it was first synthesized.

name: Meitnerium
summary: Meitnerium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Lise Meitner, the Austrian physicist who contributed to the discovery of nuclear fission.

name: Darmstadtium
summary: Darmstadtium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Darmstadt, the German city where it was first produced.

name: Roentgenium
summary: Roentgenium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Wilhelm Röntgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays.

name: Copernicium
summary: Copernicium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Nicolaus Copernicus, the astronomer who proposed the heliocentric model.

name: Nihonium
summary: Nihonium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is the first element in group 13 that is not a boron group metal and is named after Japan (Nihon).

name: Flerovium
summary: Flerovium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions in Russia.

name: Moscovium
summary: Moscovium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Moscow Oblast, Russia, where the research institute is located.

name: Livermorium
summary: Livermorium is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, USA.

name: Tennessine
summary: Tennessine is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Tennessee, USA, in recognition of contributions from Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

name: Oganesson
summary: Oganesson is a synthetic radioactive element. It is named after Yuri Oganessian, a Russian nuclear physicist, and is the heaviest known element.
